title: UMUC: Massive Open Adoption Resources

author: Karen Vignare, University of Maryland University College (UMUC)

segmentation: So I wanted to give you an update on a project that we started just last summer and you muc.
I'm going to tell you a little bit.
About us so that you understand why we decided to do this, so we started as a in the US.
An adult learning education institution that continuing education and distance education at that time was of course, correspondence.
In 1947, we serve the military of the US quite a bit in terms of education, and that means that our students are international worldwide and we are part of the system.

That is, Maryland is a small state in the United States, but we're part of a system, but we are very different than everybody else in the system because most of the other schools are either research extensive, traditional universities or dedicated to four year things like teacher, education, etc.
So we have this unique place on in the region, and we really focus on the completion of.
A bachelors degree, so the completion agenda I mean the completion for us, means often our students are bringing in their first two years of education.
Our best students are ones who and in the US in the United States have gone to community colleges.
That's where they get their first two years and hopefully have gotten an associate's degree along that way.
And many of our students have not had very successful experiences in their multiple learning environment.
So many of those students will come to us with as many as five different college experiences, of which none of them have turned into a degree.
So we are serving a underserved population, and those people who are have not yet been successful.

Completing their bachelors degree and part of that is that this mission that our president decided was very important for us was that as a state institution and many of you that are public institutions recognized that you can't change tuition rates very easily within a system, and one of the things that we could change relatively easy is the cost of materials.
Alright, so.
It is a benefit to us at U MUC as well to not have to worry about shipping materials too.

So there was this internal benefit that we were seeing, but we we're really calling our new President Javier Meares what he wants us to be is high quality, low-cost and Open Access and so to change the cost side of this, we really had to be a little bit more creative.
On how we.
We're going to do that.
So about April of last year.
President said that we were going to move to E resources in order to reduce the costs.
So from the time of April to July we had a lot of conversations internally about Ye resources.
Why not open educational resources?
So this conversation was going and I actually joined the University only June of last year.
And when I got there they involved me in these conversations very quickly.
Because I had some experience in open educational resources and access and we were able to make a commitment.
That all of our courses, all of our courses by the year 2016 will use.
We are open educational resources now.
We have a commitment.
There are some people in the University who are still very worried about whether we can actually obtain that level, because not all of the courses and not all materials exist.
Right now we're using Oers that are previously published.
We are not creating, so it may get to the point where we begin doing more creation.
Right now we're consuming an this consumption.
At our size is quite large and it's a big task in terms of curation, so we're trying to maximize the use of what everybody else has contributed in the field, and this has been.
You know an incredible journey you you can see on this graphic.
This was the other passionate reason that we've given for really trying to change what our students are paying.
The cost of educational, you know, books are publishing colleagues probably knew that they were running themselves out of business with the cost increases that we've all seen in the past.
Decade or so and.
That's another reason that we have a lot of interest in changing this for our students.
So the types of sources we started looking at, or all the ones I think many of you are very very familiar with, so we looked at open courseware.
We've looked at OSW, see, we've looked at all of, you know, at Sailor at MIT, all of the open courses out there.
We're looking at.
We are still looking at E books because at the time we don't know if we can fulfill all of our needs, right?
And some of the E books are available in terms of Open Access, not necessarily creative comments.
And then of course learning objects from places like Merlot and oh, your comment, etc.
We've been pretty successful thus.
So far, so our target was we started in the fall on after just having announced this after having made a commitment to this.
So by this fall, our commitment is to have 50% of our undergraduate courses with all of open educational resources.
We're moving really quickly at that.
We're starting to reach some stumbling blocks, and I've been trying an I'll say this to this group out here, and I have another slide at the end.
I'm really trying to look for ways that we can do better searching because of the identification to.
I mean to meet our stated learning objectives.
We're also University that are moving to competency based education.

So whether it's outcomes or whether it's competencies being able to search for, oh, we are at that level, not just the course level becomes incredibly important because we're also interested in what our panel said this morning about, particularly about personalization.
So we need many, many different resources.
One just one outcome or one competency.
So as we've moved in.
To this, we've been able to create a website for our free resources team, and there are some concerns about how public we can be about this.
Because this is a work in progress for us.
But when I say that it's because U muc.
Is a college that grew very, very quickly in the late 1990s through the 2000 range and at that point in time our competitors were the four profits, right?
So the for profit institutions in the United States?
We decided to be a little bit too much like them as as the way we think about ourselves right now and that is most of our internal working sites are all only available through intranets, right?
So I don't actually have a place on the web, which is why I've been talking to my colleague Rob over here about where.
What can I do to actually help you be able to map what it is we're doing?
I don't have a place on the web, that's.
Documenting our progress.

I'm going to so we are sharing this through slides, but most of our work is is being shared internally and being produced with a group called the instructional services and support team are part of our curators, our librarian or create curators.
And our academic director's again as a continuing Ed adult learning institution.
We do not have.
Traditional setup, so our faculty are not tenured, right?
We have probably 10 to 15% of our faculty are full time and they make up our academic director's an hour program, directores, and in some cases for large courses.
We have course level directores and as part of that then we also the rest of the faculty that work with us are adjuncts.
That means we have a lot more.
Authority to set up model classrooms and that faculty are participating because they don't really completely have a choice.
That's something we'd like to change in the future after we roll through this project as well.
So we've been able to find materials like here's an example of a free courseware in terms of that, and we're estimating our cost savings by going through what it was we you know we had.
Obviously at 90,000 students and over 1000 types of courses.
We're ordering textbooks in bulk, but we have that all of those kinds of spreadsheets left from.

When we were ordering textbooks, so some of our replacement costs are just based on what we were doing before and not necessarily based on how many students were buying the textbook because we all know that many of our students were not buying the textbooks anymore, so that's one example of where we've been able to replace with free courseware.
In this case, we're using a sailor.org ebook, and this one is again psychology, and so we've been able to actually just use one of the straight courses.
Now we're interested in having more resources, because, again, as I said earlier, what we're trying to do is figure out personalization, and we think that means adaptation.
That means adaptive learning an that requires that you have a lot more than just one.
Textbook or one resource?
Um?

And in some cases we've actually been able to find publications like for history and government courses that we can just get right from the United States Government or Maryland, or other places where they are published as Open Access.
Most of the cases or public domain so.
We're not a purist in this, so we are, you know, creative concept.
A creative comments language, but we are trying to reduce the cost to zero and use as much as we can that fits into that ovr world.
And then here's another place where we were able to get the cost down through using an ebook and books 24 by 7.
And this is something our library was able to identify, so we've got this combination of people doing all this work around curation and.
It's a very.
Time consuming process.
And here's where we are right now.
Now we did this presentation in February and we had completed 247 courses, so we're moving this along at a rapid pace, but we're very frayed about our our courses.
What we did was we chose the easier courses first.
And then started working on what we thought would be next.
Well, we've actually flipped that.
We're going to now start working on the courses we think are going to be really difficult for us to find resources so that we can still make our deadlines because we'd really like to have 100%.
Oh, we are for undergraduate students.
That's our main population.
About 75% of our students are undergraduate by the fall of 2014.
And so again, these numbers are works in progress, so I have just written on my calendar for Rob that I will give him an update June 30th on where we are so that you can see this ongoing process.
So we're estimating savings and again the estimation part of this is a little bit tricky, but it's simply based on what we know our students spent in previous years on textbooks.
So from our current spring and summer, the courses that we have this summer already that have a low, we are.
We're estimating our one time savings for our students.
One time OK is $3,000,000.
And that will repeat itself, so we're pretty, you know, happy that we're moving this quickly in terms of this, and I am working on the public.
Facing website for this, our marketing Department have has said I can have a website in June so I'm hoping that this will be one of the things that I can add to that website.
There are some things unlike the ovr stuff that move very slowly.
I asked for this website back in December so it only takes six months to get up a website that, Umm, you see you're laughing Larry, you think that's funny.
I don't think it's funny.
I wanted to go outside and do WordPress.
I was like I could do this myself people.
But anyways, there are some things that we all have.
It is with.
So as I have already said, but I'm going to say again is that we are moving into competency based education.
We're moving to adaptive learning tools.
I am looking at the end rock.

This is in the US, the national passatore for online courses has a new tool called Ed Ready and it's around developmental math and math, so I'm already looking at their materials in terms of adaptive learning.
3 minutes, OK good and then curation is a really time consuming.
Effort so.
So.
I think we have an opportunity to engage all of our faculty into new thinking in terms of of remixing and in terms of helping us crowd source the problems that we have.
I'm also very hopeful.
Again, my current president and Provost are interested in openness, but not necessarily have gotten to the point of this.
And it's on my agenda to actually.
Try to create some open learning communities at you muc.
So I don't know I'm going to one of our colleagues presentations like LR.
I wrote it wrong, so the learning resource metadata Initiative is that going to be a solution for customized searching.
I really need systematic updating.
I can't keep this curation time as a as a constant, so I think this group of people really need to focus on the next level if we're going to get people to be big users.
We've got to come up with some big solutions on searching and system it is updating at there, so I'm hoping you all will help me and that's it.
Did I do it in time?
Run the money.
OK questions.
I'm curious about one of the concerns that you identified at the end, and that is the link between O ER and the move to competency based education.
You express that as a possible concern on going, and I don't quite get that.
I wonder if you could elaborate on why that would be a concern, so I think it's because we're going to need a lot more resources.
I mean, quite frankly, if we work around a competency based education, those of you that may know places at in the US&II know this is done worldwide.
Competency based, but I have to profess.
A lack of knowledge for worldwide.
So in the US there is Western Governors University and if you know how they set up a competency, they have multiple resources for students.
So it's the work that competencies required, but it's good policy for us to have multiple resources, but we simply haven't done that in the past.
That's why I think competencies and adaptive learning are going to be further issues for us during the morning.
We had three or four times.
Kualiti being mentioned as a key problem area that needed to be addressed in Oers.
I noticed it wasn't one of the issues that you put up as as a.
As a problem.
So as somebody who's.
Searched for and sourced alot of oers for real news.
How have you found the quality?
So when I shared with you the types of sources, I mean, I think that's really how we found the quality now.
So in many repository's that we're using, we expect that most of those have a level of quality.
But then we have our internal curation, which is why I'm saying I can't sustain that on a long term basis, and so we do need more quality control.
That we can trust within our repository.
Right now it's been a combination of we know these are good places, trustworthy places.
We know these people.
We know these organizations and then we add to it our vision of you know, is this academically appropriate, etc.
So to me, I don't think there is a quality issue with this first 300.
We're a little worried about quality.
With the last you know 250 that we have to do.
I'm hopeful and I'll probably get myself into trouble that I can do a call for.
Oh, we are to be quite honest because I think the community would help in certain areas if we put out a call, but I don't know that we're willing to be that open yet.
I I don't know if you know, but Merlot hasn't had search other libraries function that lets you search 25 or 26 libraries at a time.

I know we we used to be working with Tim, so hopefully that you know that information got to that team of people and if not, I think there's a lot of good functionality that we're currently not exploring.
I think we could do you know, semi automated kinds of searches right now and.
I don't think we're doing that, and I think we're just using people time to be honest.
I mean, this is great progress, right?
But there are now issues that we have to start thinking about.
If we're going to try and make this sustain itself.
It's not so much question as a comment, I'm just picking up on this idea of how do we record and communicate what we're doing.
My suggestion would be.
To run a blog so no matter what you're doing, blog it.
Because if you blog it.

Not only is it very findable in the sense that it is integrated into search engine optimizations, and that kind of thing, but it also helps you to connect with other people who are blogging similar stuff on it.
Let's do lots of different types of content as well.
So as a record of things that are happening, blogs are very useful and.
Ideally anyone can access them on any device and so on, so it's a very open way of working, so that would be my suggestion to anyone.
Yeah, so I'm countering blogging in an internal jive platform.
That's the only place we block.
Yeah, it's not as open as it could be.
Yeah, it's not as open as I'd like it to be.
I'm working on it, there's I've only been there for 10 months.
This goes back to the quality issue, which is complicated.
Of course, even if all the.
Sings the OE are things you have now can be evaluated as high quality as they age, their quality will diminish, so you have a problem.
I know this problem for maintaining your view of the quality of that stuff.
Yeah we do and.
So.
We've basically only been doing online course reviews between every three and five years, and again I'm back to please somebody.
That really is very smart about semantic web and all of these other great technologies out there.
Let's figure out some solutions for constant updating.
I really think this is a great next step in this field for all of us.
So your you mentioned the cost and unsustainability, the curation model.
I think we all face that.
But how might you be able to share your created curated material with us so that we could say, oh, they've done a whole bunch of homework and they've got this stuff?
And maybe we should look at that first.
So can I say I'm working on it?
Um again, the reason I gave you the history of who we were even three years ago, right at three years ago we were very, you know, proprietary closed institution.

Part of this growing online market and the new president really has changed the fact that yes, we're still interested in growing our online market, but we believe we can do this through Open Access and right now we're taking in all we ours and they're behind our firewalls.
I've been asking for.
Changes in that process, I think, both the Provost.
Probably not the president, because he doesn't.
He's not thinking about the mechanics, but the Provost is behind this, but it probably will be a couple of years before I get some open courses out there and available.
You also mentioned adaptive learning, so and N Rock was the one example, but all the rest of it all.
The rest of the products out there are really commercial products.
They are commercial products, but many of them are platforms, right?

So the platforms are content agnostic, so at least if I go to a content agnostic platform, I mean there's a Dutch company realized there's another British company Kog books that you can just take in oers an use those for adaptive learning.
Right the again back to Gary's point, it's not going to be an open course, but it certainly will allow us to continue using ovr resources and that that's kind of where I am like.
Try to find open source adaptive tools and then if not at least use the content agnostic one so we can use our own ERS.
I'm not sure I quite understand that, because if it's going to be adaptive and there's a lot of work that goes into figuring out, you know the conceptual map right?
And so to just use a tool you still have to fill it with this conceptual map of our courses right now, as we're finding all we are have a conceptual map.
They have an instructional design process, so that would pull in the same ones, but it clearly is not going to be enough resources.
I mean, you know.
Many of these commercial adaptive learning tools have anywhere from 1000 to 3000.
Resources were not using that many.
For course, we're probably at best using 50K.
More questions we have time for one more.
Karen, thank you very much.
